sect1.title: Security settings
sect1.para: Using the features of this module, you can change the local security settings on the target system. The local security settings include the boot configuration, login settings, password settings, user addition settings, and file permissions.
Configuring the security settings automatically is similar to the Custom Settings in the security module available in the running system. This allows you create a customized configuration.

example.title: Security configuration
example.para: See the reference for the meaning and the possible values of the settings in the following example.

sect2.title: Password settings options
sect2.para: Change various password settings. These settings are mainly stored in the /etc/login.defs file.
Use this resource to activate one of the encryption methods currently supported. If not set, DES is configured.

DES, the Linux default method, works in all network environments, but it restricts you to passwords no longer than eight characters. MD5 allows longer passwords, thus provides more security, but some network protocols do not support this, and you may have problems with NIS. Blowfish is also supported.
Additionally, you can set up the system to check for password plausibility and length etc.

sect2.title: Linux Security Module (LSM) settings
sect2.para: In &sle; 15.4 and up, the installation control file has a new option, <lsm_select> for configuring which major Linux Security Module (LSM) will be activated by default after installation: &aa;, &selnx;, or none.

listitem.para: Optional. Configure the SELinux mode. Values: permissive, enforcing and disabled.
Optional. Major Linux Security Module to be selected during installation. Values: selinux, apparmor, or none.

sect2.title: Using &openscap; Security Policies

listitem.para: At installation time, &yast; checks a subset of the security policy rules, especially those that are hard to fix after the installation (e.g., encrypting the file system). Additionally, it installs and configures ssg-apply to run (if wanted) after the installation.
During the first boot, ssg-apply might run (depending on the user's decision) to check and/or apply the security policy.

sect2.para: The security_policy section allows selecting a security policy and deciding what ssg-apply should do during the first boot.

listitem.para: Selects the security policy to check or apply. Only the &disa; &stig; (DISA STIG) is supported by now. Use the name stig to refer to this policy. This element is mandatory.
Specify what ssg-apply should do during the first boot.
none: install and configure ssg-apply, but nothing happens during the first boot. This option is useful for modifying the policy before hardening your system.
check: check the system during the first boot. This one is the default behavior.
remediate: check and remediate the system to comply with the selected policy.
